National monument and heritage

 

     Assoc. Prof. Fatimah Lateef (Marine Parade): Mr Chairman, it is important for us to preserve and upkeep certain premises in our society with regard our heritage and culture. Most of these national monuments commemorate significant events in Singapore's short history. These earmarked buildings may also have specific history, traditional, archaeological architecture and artistic values.

 

     To date, the total number of national monuments we have is 63. How does the Preservation of Monuments Board gazette places and buildings as national monuments and how, if any, is the review done?  Can the public provide their suggestions on the additional buildings to be added?  What is MICA's approach to create greater awareness on this and help develop a sense of ownership and pride in our heritage?  What are the other plans to enhance MICA's partnership with schools and community groups?

 

     Finally, the commitment to preserve may be constrained by the importance attached to economic development, especially in the small country like Singapore. How is the balance reached and how does MICA emphasise maximising the commercial potential for old buildings?

 

Living culture and heritage

 

     Dr Ong Seh Hong (Marine Parade) (In Mandarin): [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A*.] In 2008, I pleaded in Parliament to cherish our cultural heritage for the sake of our children. I quoted a saying, "better look for the root when it is still around; better not wait for the light to be gone before passing it on."

 

     I am glad to see that "passing the light" was the highlight of this year's Chingay. When President Nathan's calligraphy "传灯" (pass the light) rose slowly in the sky and the whole stadium filled with the music of "传灯", everyone felt the deep meaning of passing the light.

 

     "传灯" lyrics were written by local writer Du Nanfa 28 years ago, and music was composed by Zhang Fan.  It did not cause much of a stir then. However, it became popular in Malaysia and China. A Chinese student studying in Singapore told me that when she was in Harbin, her school used to teach this song. They thought then that it was a Chinese folk song. Finally, it came to its birth place – Singapore. The story of this song touched me deeply.

 

     Our ancestors came from all over the world, leaving us a rich diversified cultural heritage. We have Chinese, Malay, Indian, Eurasian and Peranakan cultures. Unfortunately, we did not preserve these cultures well and slowly they disappeared from our lives. Take performing art as an example, the Chinese dialect roadside wayang, traditional Malay and Indonesia music have all gone out of fashion. Regarding languages, few young people can speak dialects; Eurasians are worried that they will lose their unique Kristang language. The meaning of traditional festivals is lost, only their commercial value is emphasised. Many street delicacies and handicrafts, which were popular when we were young, have all disappeared.

 

     Korea, on the contrary, values her traditional culture very much. They pay great attention to rituals. Kindergartens in Korea have special "ritual rooms" to familiarise children with traditional costumes, formalities in greeting, eating and serving tea. In secondary school and university, a special class is offered whereby students, dressed in traditional Korean costume, learn tea ceremony or Korean cooking.  In addition, Korea still has over 200 country schools to teach the youth humanity. They open during the summer and winter holidays and teach four main values which are similar – loyalty, filial piety, rituals and respect for seniors.

 

     Culture is the root of a nation and  race. We are a multi-cultural and multi-ethnic society. We cannot forget our roots and we need more resources to make them go deeper.  A tree will fall without roots, no matter how leafy it is. We need to have real content and a long-lasting value.  Culture should not be a still photo. It should be a part of daily life and an important cohesive power. Our support for and development of the local cultural workers are urgently needed. We need to cultivate a strong cultural army to help sink our roots deeper.

 

     We are a multi-racial society with a diversified culture. Hence, while we promote culture, we must also support ethnic cultures so that we have a flourishing diversified cultural scene. Cuisine, performance, arts and literature are means to achieve this aim. While we encourage ethnic cultural groups to play the role of preserving heritage, the Government's support is also crucial. These groups are facing two problems. First, space. Some groups rented space from NAC. Because the space is too small, they have to hold their activities outside. However, the rented space was taken back by National Arts Council (NAC) because of this. Many groups have great potential and innovative plans, but because of space constraints, their plans cannot materialise. For example, the Singapore Literature Association put forward the idea of setting up a Singapore Chinese Literature House. This is a good idea and the Association has since collected many Singapore-published books, including out-of-print editions. They are part of our cultural treasures. However, there is no place for them to exhibit the books. They tried to work with other organisations but were not successful. If these books are lost, it would be difficult to get them back.

 

     These groups also face the problem of funding. They are not-for-profit and have to raise funds constantly, yet, they still need to pay taxes like other profitable organisations.  I hope the Government can help in these two areas.


     The lyrics of " 传灯"  (pass on the light) is:


     Every river is a legend,


     From the remote hills flowing to the sea,


     Every lamp is incense,


     Lighting up gradually the dark night,


     For the great earth and grassland, sun and moon,


     For the sake of life and for blood ties,


     Every river must keep flowing,


     Every lamp must burn itself.

 

     I hope we can treasure our cultural heritage to pass on the light! Do not wait till the lamp is gone!

          The Chairman:  Mr Arthur Fong. Take both your cuts together, please.

 

 

     Mr Arthur Fong (West Coast): We are a nation of immigrants. Our forefathers hailed mostly from China and India then. But they were mostly from Southern China and Southern India. Majority of our early Chinese settlers are from the province of Fujian and our Indians migrated from Tamil Nadu.

 

     However, our immigrant stock is deepening and getting more complex in recent years. We have Chinese from the northern state of Heilongjiang, as well as Indians from all over India. It is now a common sight to see Caucasians living amongst us in our HDB estates.  Not so many years ago, many are from European states, such as the United Kingdom, France or Italy.  Now, we have quite a few residents from Eastern Europe.

 

     This addition to our population stock is a plus, but does present some challenges to our cultural heritage. On a positive note, this diversity has added to Singaporeans’ gourmet choices! We only need to look at the types of cuisines offered at the restaurants and coffee shops at many of our food haunts. We have Chinese restaurants, yu tiao from Taiwan, Chongqing steamboat, noodle shops that serve Halal food from China.


     In this regard, it is important to preserve our traditional cultures and a deeper appreciation of our heritage. Equally important is to refocus on what is our traditional culture and heritage especially in light of the changes and amidst the inter-twining social fabric of our society with the new immigrants. What is MICA and its agencies' plan to preserve our culture and heritage? 

 

Social kindness and graciousness


     Sir, my next cut. Many Singaporeans feel that we have become a fast-paced society. They are not wrong. The economic growth we have experienced and the faster pace of life can be seen and felt.  Not only is the pace of doing business faster, if we look around, the physical landscape over at our business district has changed with new office buildings readying themselves for banks and law firms to move in, the addition of transport services to cope with increased use are all testament to a bustling city.  Even older estates, like my ward in Clementi, has changed in a short 10-year period with more facilities and hip spots to serve our residents’ needs.

 

     We have been fortunate to have good economic growth allowing us to provide our people with good education.  A well-educated population should serve as the basic ingredient for a gracious and kind society.  We have first-world infrastructures, but without the kindness and social graces, we would be nothing more than gorillas having English tea in nice western suits.

 

     The English, known for their strict adherence to certain acceptable social graces have, in the last decade, had their image marred by the behaviour of football hooligans.  How are we doing in our social graces?

 

     Sir, in the early 1950s and 1960s, even right up to the 1970s, it is not uncommon to see people spitting on the street. Equally rare to see people giving up their seats to pregnant women or elderly folks on public transport. Queue-jumping is a norm and never thought to be a problem.  But in present day Singapore, although we are still far from perfect, far from the ideal society where people give way to one another, be kind to one another, and be gracious to their neighbours, the score card is not all discouraging. We still have the uniquely Singapore seat reservation practice of the "chope already" system with tissue packets in hawkers’ centres.  Although the queue-jumping, the throwing of litter out of one's flat and the parking of vehicles in the driveway of others still happen, the fact is we have improved to be kinder and a more gracious society.

 

12.15 pm

 

     We have played our part as good and gracious hosts at major events held in Singapore.  International guests from all over the world during IMF and APEC meetings have remarked how gracious and friendly Singaporeans they have had the opportunity to meet were.  We had 20,000 volunteers out in force to give foreign guests participating the Inaugural YOG a good impression of Singapore.  Graciousness of our people will indeed go a long way and is an important part of our branding.

 

     But, Sir, we cannot turn on our best behavior during these events or when we have guests and then revert to our ugly self the moment the guests leave.  We need to be kind and gracious all the time.  We need that to be part of our lives and our DNA. Well, maybe that is stretching it a little, but I made my point. We need to work at it.

 

     Can the Minister tell us what resources and initiatives his Ministry is deploying and planning for towards a kinder and more gracious society?  In my cut on public service broadcast (PBS), I shall also reiterate the role of public broadcasting and its impact on this topic.

 

National identity

 

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): With the sudden influx of foreigners to Singapore in recent years, Singaporeans are feeling a sense of anomie. One Singaporean tells me that every second person she encounters on the MRT is a foreigner, and that train carriages and public buses are a cacophony of incomprehensible tongues from far-flung outposts.


     No doubt productivity, growth and connectivity to the world are important for Singapore but what can the Government do to improve its engagement with citizens so that they once again feel that the slogan "One People, One Nation, One Singapore" means what it used to mean to Singaporeans?

 

     Mr Chairman, the Government has explained several times that Singapore needs foreigners to expand its talent pool; to work at jobs which Singaporeans are not keen to take up; to top up the population and increase the low birth rates. While the Government's arguments are sound, I am concerned about how it is communicating with the people.  Has its ability to communicate been lost in a mounting stream of immigration visas?

 

     Mr Chairman, the Government's message to the people seems to be that foreigners mean higher GDP growth.  The Government needs to improve on its message that Singapore, as home, is much more than cold economics.  What more can the Government do to make our citizens feel Singaporean again?

 

New immigrants and national identity

 

     Mr Calvin Cheng (Nominated Member): Sir, I worry about how immigration will impact the national identity of Singapore. As a country, Singapore is still an infant and its national identity is still forming. We are a state but, in many ways, not yet a nation.  Nations take many years to form and a national identity takes time to develop. The question is: as we take in these new immigrants at such a hurried pace, would it slow down the formation of our national identity? Would it make it even harder for us to become a nation? We are a state that is formed primarily by immigrants, although some have used this as an argument to argue that, as a result, we should have no problems taking in more immigrants. I disagree. 

 

     It is precisely because we are trying to form a nation out of immigrants that Singapore struggles with a national identity. We have to meld together people of different cultures, different histories, and up to half a century ago, loyalties to different nations.  Forming a nation out of these disparate communities is like cooking a soup and our ingredients have been brewing for 45 years.  But now, just as to stew is just about to be right, we throw in even more raw ingredients.  In this case, will the "stew" of our national identity ever be ready?

 

     Sir, it has often been argued a truly global city needs to always be opened to new immigrants.  Singapore strives to be a global city.  However, Singapore is not merely just a city. It is, importantly, also a state and a country hoping to be a nation. We are thus fundamentally different from and can never be a New York or a London.  New York is a global city but, nevertheless, a city in the United States of America.  London is a global city but, nevertheless, a city in the United Kingdom. A New Yorker may not be an American, but there are Americans who do not live in New York. A Londoner may not necessarily be a member of the British nation.

 

     Singapore is different.  It is a city-state – a city and a state. We cannot be a global city that is also part of a wider not so global and fundamentally local state.  For us, it is one and the same.  I thus wonder whether we are trying to square a circle.  If Singapore is ever truly to become a global city, does that mean, by definition, we will never be a nation? 

 

     Sir, much has been done about the integration of new immigrants and this is to be applauded.  However, in order to integrate them, we need a strong identity to integrate them into in the first place. Everywhere in the world, countries have to deal with the integration of new immigrants but older nations with a strong identity find it easier to do so.  If we do not even know who we are, how can we expect our new citizens to become more like us?

 

     Sir, much as I believe that we need new immigrants to counter our declining birth rates and add to the vibrancy of our city, I think we need a certain ratio of a core group of Singaporeans to be maintained.  How do we define these Singaporeans?  It is never easy to draw a clear line but I will give you a reply that I gave my mainland Chinese friends.  Many of us from my generation will be the third generation on our island.  Our grandparents came here.  I explained to them that our surname seemed weird to a speaker of Mandarin because our ancestors came from southern China.  Many of us in our 30s and 40s were born here post-independence and grew up in Singapore. We have many friends of many races but we all speak in the same accent. All of these, the shared culture background, the shared history of parents, our grandparents, bind us together and help us form a common identity. I am sure the Indians and Malays have similar stories as well and, together, our stories form our identity.

 

     Sir, we cannot be xenophobic.  A xenophobic, inward-looking nation cannot prosper especially one as small as Singapore. However, a country that keeps taking in new people soon find itself having an identity crisis.  This is being seen all over the world.

 

     The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom recently declared the failure of their policy of multi-culturalism.  Germany is struggling with its Turkish immigrant population. Even America, the mother of all immigrant nations, wonders what it would be like when ethnic minorities outnumber those that have been in the United States since independence.  If these old countries have problems, what more a country like us which is only 45 years in their making?  A balance thus needs to be struck for Singapore.  Otherwise, we will never have a national identity to integrate our new immigrants into.

 

Changing rules for a new social impact

 

     Miss Penny Low (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Mr Chairman, what does the Facebook, Wikipedia, YouTube and the Egyptian revolution have in common? They are all phenomenal – first growth, user-led movements that re-defined the rules of engagement between the private, public and people sectors. 

 

     While top-down centralised institutions and initiatives still have their place, the distributed preferential network of people-oriented and people-originated initiatives, linked by shared interest, strengthened by the pervasiveness of social media and open borders, are gaining ground.  Interestingly, the recent ground-up Egyptian revolution was led not by political groups but shared-interest groups.  Today's local leaders are at the heart of their communities. They inspire communities, let them decide what makes sense and galvanise groups for collective action.

 

     This presents tremendous risks and opportunities for the Government. A case in point: the Egyptian revolution although successfully overthrew the entrenched Mubarak regime, offers no clear solution or leaders to Egypt's problems. Its people continue to suffer. We must not let this happen to Singapore. We need to understand this new phenomenon and urgently close the gap between the people and the public sector.

 

     So, how do we close the gap?  Simply up the collaboration quotient between the public and people sectors.  Invest heavily in people sector events and initiatives.  Help them scale up and scale overseas, just like we did with the private sector. The good news here is that we do have that experience with the private sector and we can transfer those know-how and skill-set to the people sector as well.

 

     The top-down approach, whether Government plans and procures all things from MNCs to IOs to global events, takes care of citizens from cradle to grave, has its own limitations. While we enjoy imported top chefs and glitzy events to the tune of tens of millions of dollars, people are not content being mere consumers anymore. Singaporeans are better educated and self-confident today. They want to be producers and need bold support to develop and scale Singapore and people-oriented events and ventures.  Perhaps, the Government will urge that it has supported major local events, and I agree.  However, a closer look will tell us that many of these events originated as Government or agency-led events. While it serves its industry purpose, it does little to build the new social compact. Some observed that the Government appears to be less patient with local dark horses and too eager in bringing in foreign brand names.  Undeniably, imports are quick wins but can be passing fancies.  The former, however, will add buzz to the Singapore scene more permanently, cultivate a sense of achievement, pride and appreciation amongst Singaporeans and, at the same time, grow an exportable sector that will bring both financial gain and reputation to Singapore.

 

     I urge the Government to channel bold support towards people sector initiatives that can potentially shine on the regional and global stage. Go beyond that of financial support, facilitate with know-how and network and build a pipeline of people/public sector success stories that has its heart rooted in Singapore even as they spread their wings and Singapore's interest and Singaporeans along.

 

   Sir, the Government cannot know all or do all, but it must eye-ball the changing rules for a new social compact and the new rules require that the Government be more people-centric, create support frameworks that incentivise and facilitate people to be at their best.  Ultimately, people have to be responsible for their own future.  This would be the most sensible and effective way of ensuring that we build a cohesive social compact that cultivates in the inter-dependence, resilience, active citizenry  to provide the peace and prosperity in nation-building.  Sir, the more we celebrate locally, and people-originated events, enterprise and ventures, the more there will be to celebrate.

 

Cool Singapore

 

     Mr Chan Soo Sen (Joo Chiat): Mr Chairman, some four years ago in this House, I commented that Singapore is seen to be good and not seen to be cool.  I also argued that having a cool image is actually very vital in the next stage of economic development because we cannot compete on cost so we must compete on innovation and creation.  Having a cool image allows people to want to pay more for things that are created in Singapore. That is why people are prepared to pay hundred times the price for an Italian wallet rather than the Thai ones because Italy is seen to be more cool than Thailand.

 

     I must say that we have made good progress since then.  We have staged a successful Asian Youth Games, absolutely spectacular. We had a charming Chingay parade and we have created new brand names such as "Awfully Chocolate".  I think these are good progress but we have got to go further, both in terms of breadth and depth.

 

     Let us examine Singapore's strengths.  Singapore's uniqueness lies in our multi-culturalism. We would be seen to be cool if we could blend our many cultures to create products, services as well as performances that are uniquely Singapore.  I think we were seen to be even more cool if, wherever we regionalise, we could also seamlessly blend with the cultures of the host countries that we go to create products, services, and maybe cultural performances that are truly unique, and that both we and our host countries are proud of.

 

     I feel that to do this, we need to bring together people with deep knowledge in different cultures, as well as people with good creative and business sense, get them to work together, bounce their heads with each other, impact each other's professionalism in a stimulating as well as out-of-the-box environment.  In this way, we could generate, nurture and grow the sparks of creativity.  But all these ideas will still need to have things like incubators and the various start-up support schemes in order to make them into reality.  All these would need funding support.

     This is different from what Mr Low mentioned, which is about the protection of the privacy of individuals.  So, one, we are doing is the Consumer Data Protection Law; and the other point he mentioned is protecting the privacy of individuals.  Privacy generally relates to the prevention of intrusion into an individual's private life; while data protection concerns the protection of an individual's personal data against misuse.  An intrusion into an individual's private life need not necessarily be derived from a misuse of an individual's personal data and vice versa.  And so they cannot be said to be one and the same.  For example, privacy issues include the taking of photographs by a stranger of a person performing an activity – eating, exercising, etc.  But this alone would not constitute a data protection issue.  So what we are doing, first and foremost, is to govern the proper processing of personal information such as the collection, the use, the disclosure and the transfer of this data, and to make sure that this is appropriately regulated.
 
     Having said all these, the public must remain vigilant when giving out personal information, when filling up survey, contest or registration forms, the terms and conditions ought to be read closely to determine how personal details will be used; and we will also ensure businesses refrain from collecting personal information other than what is necessary and should inform consumers about the purpose of collection and ensure that the information is used only for that purpose stated.

     The second concern is the unknowing incurrence of high data roaming charges.  Currently, mobile operators have several measures to protect consumers against high data roaming charges.  These include SMS alerts on usage, special plans which cap data roaming charges with unlimited usage in selected countries, and so on.  Consumers, of course, can also switch off the data roaming function on their mobile phones.  Nonetheless, we know that consumers still face difficulties.  To further protect consumers against data roaming bill shocks, IDA intends to require all mobile operators to offer consumers two new options.  The first is a free data roaming service suspension option that caps consumers' data roaming usage at a specified dollar quantum in data roaming charges.  The service is automatically suspended once your data roaming reaches this specified dollar quantum that you have set.  The second is to provide more convenient means for consumers to de-activate data services before travelling overseas.  These measures will allow consumers to better control their usage of data roaming services and prevent bill shocks.  We will also encourage all consumers to be diligent, seek to understand the prices and terms of mobile services, and the features of the smartphones that they are using.  Ultimately, this is the best assurance that consumers do not face any surprises in their bills.

 

     The third concern is on the actual broadband speeds which consumers experience.  Presently, IDA has in place a quality of service framework for fixed-line broadband services, covering network availability, latency and international bandwidth utilisation, but not minimum standards on broadband speeds.  In IDA's public consultation on network neutrality, the IDA proposed that service providers improve information transparency on the expected average broadband speeds achievable for their broadband plans.  As Mr Low has noted, the service providers did not welcome this proposal.  IDA understands that there are many factors affecting consumers' fixed-line and mobile broadband surfing experience, such as the types of equipment, devices and applications being used and the website content provider's system configuration, bandwidth connection, and so on.  But, nonetheless, to enable consumers to make more informed choices between service providers, IDA intends to require service providers to publish the typical speeds which consumers can expect of both fixed and mobile broadband services, in addition to the theoretical maximum speeds advertised.  And IDA will also publish its own audit of the speeds and the methodology it uses in carrying out its audit.
 
     A fourth area of concern, highlighted by Mr Lim, is the mobile coverage along the coastline and within buildings and tunnels.  IDA is aware of signals spilling over from overseas mobile operators near the coastline, and is constantly working with their Malaysian and Indonesian counterparts to minimise signal spillage.  But this is the nature of radio-frequency signals, they are no respecter of borders, they do not carry a passport when they cross borders.  And so it is not totally possible to eradicate such spillage given the close proximity with our neighbouring countries.  Indeed, mobile phone users in our neighbouring countries also experience signal spillage from Singapore mobile operators.  This is one area where we strongly encourage end-users to play their part by configuring, manually, if necessary, their mobile phones to select the desired local network rather than through auto-roaming features. 

 

     With regard to mobile coverage within buildings and tunnels, IDA has in place Quality of Service standards that require 95% coverage on street level and in road and MRT tunnels as well as 85% coverage at public access areas within buildings, including basement areas with services to the public, such as shops, food courts and supermarkets.  However, where there may be good mobile coverage in one area, there could be specific spots in the same area where coverage is not optimal as mobile signals could be blocked due to the building structure or technical limitations.  While IDA has not imposed any financial penalty on the three mobile operators as they are able to meet the current QoS, IDA has imposed financial penalties on the operators for delaying rollout of 3G coverage at certain MRT tunnels.  So, no penalties for buildings because they are actually currently meeting the QoS but penalties have been imposed on them because they have delayed the rollout of 3G coverage in MRT tunnels.  IDA has directed the operators to achieve full 3G tunnel coverage by end July this year.

     Mr Calvin Cheng: Sir, recent events in the Middle East have shown the power of the Internet to not only change the political landscape of a country, but to even help overthrow governments.      Sir, it seems that the Internet is a technology that not only disrupts businesses but also politics. It may go even further than that. To many who have adopted the Internet in their adult lives, it may seem like a technology, something they have learnt to use. However, to those who have grown up with the Internet – the Internet generation – the Internet is not merely a technology, it is their way of life.


     The Internet is estimated to have started in the mid-1990s. Those who are 21 to 30 at the next election in Singapore, which may be in a matter of weeks, would have been five to 14 in 1995. This generation has practically grown up with the Internet. They do not remember a world where the Internet did not exist. Sir, this generation, as a result, behaves and thinks in ways that their elders cannot understand. This is the generation that puts their lives up for public display on blogs, writes about their innermost thoughts and shares it with thousands of strangers. This is the generation that makes friends and keeps friends not through going down to tea dances, but through social networks. This is the generation that would tweet about the most private moments of their lives.


     Whatever information they offer freely of themselves, they demand it also. Do not know a thing – well, "Google" it – and the information is expected in milliseconds. This is the generation that does not pull out a copy of Encyclopaedia Britannica to research but expects to find the gospel truth on Wikipedia. They think they are entitled to say whatever they want, however they want, whenever they want. They think that the Internet has finally given ordinary people the power to seek the truth from people who they think are hiding the truth, and they get angry when they think they are being lied to. In China, nothing is more fearsome than a flesh-search (人肉收索), where millions of netizens combine efforts to ferret out information about people they think might have done wrong.


     The impact of the Internet and the Internet generation will be difficult to predict in the next election. Already at the last election in 2006, we have seen an inkling of what may happen. There was already use of some message boards and socio-political blogs to spread information. No doubt, this election will see even more of this and the pervasive use of Facebook and Twitter to gather support. The young may not bother turning up at rallies, but you can be sure that they will turn to the Internet to gather every bit of information they can find.


     Sir, governments around the world have reacted to this change often with regulation. This is pointless.  Although Egypt has shown that one can pull the plug on the Internet, this would be cutting off one’s nose to spite one’s face. No country can function without an Internet connection to the outside world nowadays, especially one as open as Singapore. And even China has struggled to maintain its great firewall. Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) are so readily available nowadays that to try to put up a firewall around an entire country is a joke. Moreover, with anonymous proxy servers all over the world, everybody can be anybody. Chasing anonymous people around cyberspace is like trying to catch a ghost – time-consuming and ultimately futile.


     Instead, I would rather that the Government uses education as its reaction to the Internet, to make sure that the Internet generation has a beneficial rather than a pernicious effect on the political landscape. Firstly, netizens have to know that the social rules that apply to the real world should apply to the Internet as well. If one is a polite person in the real world, why would one want to turn into a rude, ranting obnoxious maniac on the Internet? If one would not be racist or insult other people’s religions, or slander another human being normally, why would one think it is okay to do so just because it is a blog or a Facebook account? If anonymity means that you are free to become a beast, then a beast you are, Internet or not. Be the person you would be on the Internet, as you are in the real world.


     Secondly, whereas education in the past focused on rote-learning information, memorising historical facts, and swotting up knowledge, education now has to focus on information processing, analytical skills and the ability to differentiate fact from fiction. In the past, if I read something in Encyclopaedia Britannica, I know it to be a fact, and I can safely commit it to memory. Now if I read something on Wikipedia or on the Internet, I have to first ask myself whether it is really a fact. This is crucial. Our Internet generation has to be equipped with the critical thinking skills to sift through the tons of misinformation and disinformation to be found on the Internet, to be able to tell truths from lies, and to carry a healthy dose of scepticism into cyberspace. This is crucial to the political process, as a democracy functions well only if the electorate is able to make reasoned and rational choices made on correct information. The next election will no doubt see some anonymous irresponsible people spreading lies, mistruths and unfounded rumours in cyberspace. Trying to clamp down on these troublemakers may be difficult; much better to equip our people in the long run with the critical thinking skills to ascertain fact from fiction.

     The Senior Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."
 

     Sir, this Bill, when passed, will give effect to the Convention on the Safety of United Nations and Associated Personnel, as well as the Optional Protocol to the Convention. Drafted in response to the growing number of casualties and fatalities resulting from deliberate attacks on UN workers engaged in peacekeeping operations, the Convention aims to ensure that perpetrators of such attacks are brought to justice. In recognition of the risks that UN and associated personnel also face in non-peacekeeping missions, the Optional Protocol expands the scope of protection to the Convention to UN non-peacekeeping missions such as humanitarian relief operations, and delivery of political or development assistance in peace building.

 

     Although Singapore does not host any UN operations, it is our duty as a responsible member of the international community to put in place measures to protect those who carry out the important work undertaken by the UN in its various missions around the world. Members can see some of the photographs on the screen [indicating ], just to add some colours to this rather grey presentation.  Singapore has deployed personnel from the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF), Singapore Police Force (SPF) and Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) to various UN missions. To date, more than 1,500 of our SAF personnel and over 475 SPF officers have participated in UN operations in countries as diverse as Namibia, Cambodia, Nepal and Timor-Leste. 

 

     Apart from peacekeeping missions, our uniformed personnel have also participated in various UN humanitarian assistance operations. For instance, about 20 of our SCDF officers have been deployed to assist in UN Disaster Assessment and Coordination (UNDAC) missions and Asia-Pacific Humanitarian Partnership teams to provide emergency humanitarian aid in places like New Zealand, following the recent earthquake in Christchurch, Indonesia, Myanmar, Papua New Guinea, Pakistan and the Philippines.

 

     SAF personnel were also deployed under the ambit of UNDAC to assist in humanitarian efforts in Pakistan in August last year after monsoon rains triggered the worst floods in more than 80 years of the country's history. They were similarly involved in humanitarian aid operations in the Philippines following Typhoon Lupit in October 2009, and in Thailand in the aftermath of the 2004 tsunami. Apart from our uniformed personnel, Singaporean civilians are also increasingly involved in humanitarian relief work abroad, for example, Mercy Relief, Red Cross, which may include UN operations. It is therefore in Singapore's interest to ensure that Singaporeans, whether uniformed personnel or civilians, engaged in present and future UN operations are afforded the protection and recourse they deserve.

 

     The provisions of our Penal Code by and large address our obligations under the Convention on the Safety of United Nations and Associated Personnel if such offences were to be committed in Singapore. Many of the Convention's provisions and obligations are similar to those found in the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of Crimes against Internationally Protected Persons, including Diplomatic Agents which Singapore became party to in 2008. Thus, the UN Personnel Bill, while covering a different group of individuals, is closely modelled on the Internationally Protected Persons Act (IPP Act) that was passed in 2008. The present UN Personnel Bill extends Singapore's jurisdiction to deal with specific crimes against UN workers outside Singapore. The Bill also provides for mutual legal assistance and extradition procedures in relation to individuals accused of offences under the Convention.

 

     Sir, I will now touch on the key provisions of the Bill.

 

Definition of UN worker and UN operation

 

     Clause 3 of the Bill defines who is a "UN worker" in accordance with Article 1 of the Convention. Under the Convention, "UN workers" refer to individuals engaged or deployed by the UN Secretary-General as members of the military, police or civilian components of a UN operation. The Bill also covers officials and experts on mission of the UN, the IAEA and specialised agencies who are present in an official capacity in the area where a UN operation is conducted. The Bill further protects other individuals who may be assigned by the government of a State, intergovernmental organisation, or humanitarian agency under an agreement with the UN, to carry out activities in support of a UN operation. 

 

 

Where there is a doubt as to whether a particular person is a "UN worker" at a particular point in time, the Bill provides for the Minister for Foreign Affairs to give a written certificate affirming his status. This certificate is evidence of that fact unless the contrary is proved.

     Clause 3 of the Bill also defines a UN operation as any operation established by the competent organ of the UN, conducted under the UN's authority or control and whose purpose is the maintenance or restoration of international peace and security.  It could also be an operation which has been declared by the UN as one where there is exceptional risk to the safety of participating personnel.  As the Optional Protocol to the Convention extends protection to personnel in UN non-peacekeeping missions, the Bill also covers all other UN operations conducted under UN authority and control for the purpose of delivering humanitarian, political or development assistance or emergency humanitarian assistance.

 

Extra-territorial jurisdiction for offences against UN workers/offences against premises or vehicles of UN workers

 

     A number of provisions in the Bill provide for extra-territorial jurisdiction in relation to certain offences against UN workers. Any person who commits an act outside Singapore, which constitutes an offence under the Convention, will be deemed to have committed the offence here.  This extra-territorial element in the Bill affords us the ability and flexibility to prosecute any offender found in our territory if he is not extradited.

 

     In particular, clause 4 of the Bill confers extra-territorial jurisdiction in relation to offences listed in the First Schedule (such as murder, kidnapping, grievous hurt).  Clause 5 confers extra-territorial jurisdiction for offences listed in the Second Schedule which are committed against the official premises, place of residence or any vehicle used by a UN worker.  Clause 6 of the Bill makes it an offence, both within Singapore as well as outside Singapore, to threaten to commit an offence against a UN worker, his official premises, place of residence or vehicle used by him. Clause 7 confers extra-territorial jurisdiction for the abetment of, a conspiracy or an attempt to commit an offence against a UN worker.

 

     These provisions help to ensure that perpetrators do not escape punishment regardless of who they are and where the offence was committed, which is a key objective of the Convention.

 

Presumption of knowledge

 

     Individuals who are charged for the offences specified in clauses 4 to 7 of this Bill will be presumed to know that the target of his actions was a UN worker and the status of the premises or vehicle concerned.  This presumption is rebuttable and only applies after the prosecution has shown that the victim or premises or vehicle had UN status.  Such a provision in criminal legislation is not unprecedented.  The Internationally Protected Persons Act contains a similar provision.

 

Withholding information

 

     To prevent or prosecute offences against UN workers effectively, early intervention is critical and everyone must play his part.  Having prior information of plans to commit offences against a UN worker allows our Government to intervene or take action before these plans are carried out.  Therefore, clause 9 of the Bill requires any person who has information that can prevent the commission of an offence against a UN worker, or which is useful to secure the apprehension, prosecution or conviction of the offender, to come forward and provide the information to the authorities.  There are safeguards for a person who provides the information in good faith, such as protection against any civil or criminal proceedings.  Conversely, failure to disclose such information renders a person liable to a fine not exceeding S$50,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years or both.

 

Extradition and mutual legal assistance

 

     Sir, the Convention requires States Parties either to extradite a Convention offender present in its territory or to submit him to the competent authorities for the purpose of prosecution.  Under the Extradition Act, extradition to or from a declared Commonwealth country may be effected without an extradition treaty.  However when an extradition request is received from a non-Commonwealth country that is party to the Convention but which does not have a bilateral extradition treaty with Singapore, clause 11 of the Bill provides that the Minister for Law may issue a notification in the Gazette under section 4 of the Extradition Act to apply the Act.  Clause 11 also allows this for cases where there is an existing bilateral extradition treaty between Singapore and a State Party to the Convention but the bilateral extradition treaty does not cover offences against UN workers.  Clause 12 provides for similar powers as regards Parties to the Protocol and acts which are offences by virtue of the Protocol.

 

     To facilitate mutual legal assistance between States Parties to the Convention, clause 10 of the Bill provides that assistance under Part III of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act may be provided by Singapore to a Convention country with respect to offences against UN workers.  Under the same clause, an offence against a UN worker shall be deemed not to be an offence of a political nature.  This is to prevent anyone from blocking mutual legal assistance or extradition on the grounds that the offence in question is politically motivated.


     In conclusion, Sir, as a responsible member of the UN, Singapore's implementation of the United Nations Personnel Bill and adoption of the Optional Protocol would demonstrate our clear commitment to the protection of UN workers.  It ensures that perpetrators of crimes against UN and associated personnel will not find a safe haven in Singapore.

     (b) enhance NEA’s pollution control powers.

 

Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS) 

    

     The use of more energy efficient household appliances benefits families as well as the environment.  Families save on their electricity bills.  Limited natural resources are conserved.    

 

     Household air-conditioners and refrigerators are the two highest energy users for a typical household, together accounting for about 50% of the household energy consumption.  Energy efficient air-conditioners and refrigerators generally have lower lifecycle costs compared to inefficient ones.  For instance, the lifecycle cost of a typical 4-tick household air-conditioner is about 35% less than that of a 1-tick model.  Similarly, for refrigerators, the lifecycle cost of a 4-tick refrigerator is about 27% less than that of a 1-tick model.  Changing from a 1-tick air-conditioner to a 4-tick air-conditioner can help a typical household save about $355 in electricity a year, while changing from a 1-tick refrigerator to a 4-tick refrigerator can help a household save about $100 a year. 

 

     Since 2008, we had Mandatory Energy Labelling to provide households with information on the energy efficiency models of air-conditioners and refrigerators so that they can make more informed choices and take into account energy use when purchasing these appliances.  Over the years, we have seen the market move gradually towards more energy-efficient appliances.  To lock in and extend the gains we have made, I announced in 2009 that the Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS) scheme will be implemented this year for household air-conditioners and refrigerators.

 

     MEPS, which will be implemented through clauses 16 and 17 of the Bill and subsidiary legislation to be made, will remove all the most inefficient zero-tick air-conditioners and refrigerators, and some of the 1-tick and 2-tick models from the market.  This will come into effect in September 2011.

 

     With the introduction of MEPS, a wide range of brands and models will continue to remain available on the market.  Over time, as more efficient models enter the market and costs come down further, we will consider gradually ratcheting up the standards.

 

Enhancements to enforcement
 

     To ensure our pollution control measures continue to support better environmental quality, the Bill also contains amendments to enhance NEA’s enforcement powers for pollution control.  As Singapore is a small city-state with industries located close to residential areas, careful control of pollution is necessary to ensure we continue to enjoy a high quality environment.

 

     First, the amendments will let NEA impose requirements on companies whose activities may adversely affect the environment. NEA will be empowered to make regulations to reduce construction noise through the restriction or prohibition of construction work during certain hours.  The Director-General will be empowered to stop work on premises to prevent, cease or reduce air pollution, and to require an owner or occupier to remove from his premises for disposal any material or equipment contaminated with hazardous substances.

 

     NEA will be allowed to recover emergency clean-up costs from polluters and to initiate prosecutions against officers of companies which have committed offences without the need for the company to have been first convicted of the offence.  This is to prevent a director from avoiding prosecution by de-registering his company before the company is convicted.

 

     It will also be made an offence for an owner or occupier of scheduled premises to breach NEA’s licensing conditions, and for companies to carry out industrial plant works, such as building a chemical production plant, without NEA’s clearance certificate. 

 

     In addition, the Bill will allow NEA to increase the effectiveness of its enforcement operations.  NEA will be able to appoint auxiliary police to aid its own officers in enforcing the EPMA, which would include stopping and testing smoky or noisy vehicles.
